questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

 

This image shows the mid-clavicular line, xiphoid process, and costal margin.

 

The examiner marks a laterally convex line that runs from the third costal cartilage, which is located about three spaces below the second costal cartilage (as shown by the sternal angle), to the sixth costal cartilage. The distance between this line and the sternal margin is around 1.2 cm. This imply that the area designated matches the right atrium's surface marking.

 

An average adult's projected cardiac borders onto the front chest wall form a trapezium shape. The percussion approach can be used to map this out by checking for cardiac dullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct typically ascends in the posterior mediastinum and does not correspond to the surface marking in the image which is more anterior and lateral.

 

Option C. Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments: These segments are located more inferiorly in the lung fields and do not correspond to the area marked which is on the chest wall at the level of the heart.

 

Option D. Hilum: The hilum of the lung, where structures enter and exit the lung, is located more laterally than the area marked. It does not align with the vertical placement of the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

 

  • ﻿﻿Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1-2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately
  • 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • ﻿﻿Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic low back pain and restricted spinal mobility. MRI shows degeneration of the structure composed of the cartilage shown in the image. Which region is most likely to be affected? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intervertebral disc

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows elastic cartilage, but the question is twisted to focus on fibrocartilage which is found in intervertebral discs. 

 

Fibrocartilage characteristics include:

  • Thick bundles of collagen fibers
  • High tensile strength
  • Excellent shock absorption
  • Rigid and inflexible nature

 

In intervertebral disc degeneration:

  • Loss of disc height
  • Reduced shock absorption
  • Decreased spinal mobility
  • Chronic back pain
  • Potential nerve compression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiglottis:

  • Contains elastic cartilage (shown in image)
  • Yellowish in appearance
  • Highly flexible and resilient
  • Not associated with chronic back pain

 

Option B. External ear:

  • Contains elastic cartilage (shown in image)
  • Maintains shape while allowing flexibility
  • Not related to spinal pathology

 

Option D. Articular surface of knee joint:

  • Contains hyaline cartilage
  • Blue-white, shiny appearance
  • Moderate strength and flexibility
  • Different histological appearance from image

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The distribution and properties of different cartilage types is crucial for correlating structural changes with clinical presentations. Fibrocartilage in intervertebral discs is essential for spine stability and mobility, and its degeneration leads to specific clinical symptoms.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is incorrect ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.

 

Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Usually it takes anywhere between 1 to 12 months for the anatomical closure of foramen ovale

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development. Hence, this statement is accurate.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

The genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve that arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves. It descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from the lateral border of the muscle. It then divides into two branches: The genital branch, which supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the mons pubis, labia majora or scrotum, and cremaster muscle in males.

 

The femoral branch, which passes laterally over the iliacus muscle and descends along the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle. It supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the femoral triangle and the upper anterior thigh.

 

In addition to its sensory functions, the genitofemoral nerve also provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males, which raises the testes towards the body in response to cold or other stimuli. Dysfunction of the genitofemoral nerve can lead to sensory loss or motor weakness in the areas it innervates.

 

 

During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia is typically administered in the area inferior to the inguinal ligament and close to the femoral pulse. Among the given options, the genitofemoral nerve is the one most likely to be anesthetized during this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the dorsal divisions of the ventral rami of the L2-L4 spinal nerves. It descends through the iliopsoas muscle and enters the femoral triangle, lateral to the femoral vessels. The femoral nerve primarily supplies muscles in the anterior compartment of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. While it is in close proximity to the femoral vein, it is not the primary nerve targeted during femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh: This nerve originates from the L2-L3 levels of the lumbar plexus. It travels inferiorly and exits the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, close to the anterior superior iliac spine, to supply the skin on the lateral aspect of the thigh. While it is near the inguinal ligament, its location is more lateral compared to the site of femoral vein catheterization, making it less likely to be affected.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve arises from the L1 level of the lumbar plexus. It travels through the inguinal canal and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the groin, mons pubis, and scrotum or labium majus. The course and distribution of this nerve make it less relevant for femoral vein catheterization, which occurs more medially and inferiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1-L2 levels of the lumbar plexus. It descends on the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle and then splits into two branches: the genital and femoral branches. The femoral branch pierces the fascia lata to provide sensory innervation to a small area of skin over the femoral triangle. Given its anatomical location and course, this nerve is likely to be anesthetized during femoral vein catheterization.

questions.text: Which of the following finger has two dorsal interossei muscles? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Middle finger

 

Explanation:

 

The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles flanking it. One is positioned between the index and middle fingers, and the other is positioned between the middle and ring fingers.

 

This anatomical configuration allows the middle finger to be abducted in both directions: towards the index finger and towards the ring finger.

 

 

The dorsal interossei muscles are four bipennate muscles located between the metacarpal bones in the hand. They are named "dorsal" because they are located on the dorsum (back) of the hand, and "interossei" means between bones. Their main action is to abduct the fingers away from the axial line, which runs down the center of the third (middle) finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Index finger: This finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts the index finger away from the middle finger.

 

Option B. Little finger: The little finger also has one dorsal interosseous muscle. This muscle abducts the little finger away from the ring finger.

 

Option D. Ring finger: The ring finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts it away from the little finger.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the green muscles marked? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Depression

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in green is the lateral pterygoid muscle, and its primary function among the given options is depression of the mandible (opening the mouth). "Depression is brought about mainly by the lateral pterygoid" and it is "indispensible for actively opening the mouth."

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  • Depression of the mandible (primary active opener of the mouth)
  • Protrusion of the mandible
  • When one side contracts, it turns the chin to the opposite side

 

While the digastric, geniohyoid, and mylohyoid muscles assist in depression, they primarily help when the mouth is opened wide or against resistance. The lateral pterygoid is the main muscle responsible for actively opening the mouth during normal function.
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protrusion:

 

  • Protrusion refers to the forward movement of the lower jaw (mandible).
  • The lateral along with medial pterygoid muscle are responsible for protruding the mandible. When this muscle contracts on both sides, it causes the jaw to move forward.

 

Option B. Elevation:

 

  • Elevation refers to the upward movement of the mandible, closing the mouth.
  • The primary muscles responsible for jaw elevation are the masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles. The lateral pterygoid's main function is not jaw elevation but rather protrusion.

 

Option D. Retraction:

 

  • Retraction refers to the backward movement of the mandible.
  • The primary muscles involved in jaw retraction are the temporalis and the posterior fibers of the digastric muscle. The lateral pterygoid is not primarily responsible for this movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Match the following : (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopia. The MRI shows a mass in the structure marked in the image. Identify the structure: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pituitary gland

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pituitary gland. It is located at the base of the brain within the sella turcica of the sphenoid bone, attached to the hypothalamus by the infundibulum. The anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis) produces several hormones including prolactin, growth hormone, and other tropic hormones. 

 

Pituitary tumors, particularly prolactinomas, can present with:

 

  • Galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia
  • Amenorrhea in women
  • Visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopia) due to compression of the optic chiasm

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: Located posterior to the third ventricle in the midline, this endocrine gland produces melatonin. Unlike the pituitary, pineal tumors typically present with Parinaud's syndrome and hydrocephalus due to compression of the tectal plate and cerebral aqueduct.

 

Option B. Falx cerebri: This is a dural fold separating the cerebral hemispheres, not an endocrine structure. Lesions here would not cause endocrine symptoms.

 

Option C. Fornix: A white matter tract connecting the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, part of the Papez circuit. Lesions here cause memory impairment rather than endocrine dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The anatomical location of the pituitary gland, its relationship to surrounding structures, and the clinical presentation of pituitary tumors, particularly the classic triad of galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopia in prolactin-secreting adenomas.

choices.text: Left Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius
Right Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius

questions.text: A patient was asked to stand on his left leg and his right hip falls down, which among the following muscles will be affected in this case? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius

 

Left gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles will be affected in this case.

 

The left gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles (supplied by the left superior gluteal nerve) are primarily responsible for abduction and stabilization of the hip joint, especially when standing on one leg.

 

Weakness or dysfunction in these muscles on the left side could lead to a drop in the right hip when the patient tries to stand on the left leg. This is because the left hip abductors are unable to maintain proper alignment and stability of the pelvis (Positive Trendelenburg's sign)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Gluteus Maximus: The gluteus maximus is primarily responsible for hip extension and external rotation but has a lesser role in hip abduction. Weakness or dysfunction of the gluteus maximus may not be the primary cause of the right hip dropping in this specific scenario.

 

Option C. Right Gluteus Minimus and Gluteus Medius: The right gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles on the same side as the falling hip are less likely to be the primary cause of the right hip dropping when standing on the left leg. These muscles would typically work to elevate and stabilize the right hip..

 

Option D.  Quadriceps: The quadriceps muscles are located in the front of the thigh and primarily function to extend the knee. While they play a role in maintaining knee stability during activities like standing, they are not the primary muscles responsible for stabilizing the hip during single-leg stance. Therefore, weakness in the quadriceps may not directly cause the right hip to drop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness in the left gluteus minimus and medius is indicated by the positive Trendelenburg's sign, where the pelvis drops on the side of the non-weight bearing leg (right), due to inadequate stabilization by these muscles on the standing leg (left).

questions.text: All of the following cranial nerve nuclei are part of special visceral afferent column except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

The trochlear nerve nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent column (GSE), not the special visceral afferent column. Special visceral afferent refers to sensory information associated with taste and smell.

 

The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the orbit's superior oblique muscle.

 

The neurons of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column innervate the extrinsic ocular and tongue muscles (III, IV, VI, and XII cranial nerves).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • Sensory Component: The facial nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via the chorda tympani branch).
  • Motor Component: The facial nerve also contains motor fibers responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):

 

  • Sensory Component: The vagus nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the epiglottis and the root of the tongue.
  • Motor Component: The vagus nerve has a wide range of motor functions, including control of the muscles involved in swallowing and vocalization, as well as autonomic functions.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX):

 

  • Sensory Component: The glossopharyngeal nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and sensory input from the oropharynx.
  • Motor Component: It also has motor functions, including control of certain muscles involved in swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: Nucleus pulposus is derived from? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mark b

 

Explanation:

 

  • The notochord is a rod-like structure that forms during embryonic development and serves as the foundation for the future vertebral column.
  • The nucleus pulposus, the central gel-like core of the intervertebral disc, is derived from the notochord. The notochord initially provides structural support to the developing embryo and later contributes to the formation of the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mark d. Ectoderm:

 

  • The ectoderm is another primary germ layer of the developing embryo and gives rise to structures such as the nervous system, skin, and epidermal tissues.
  • The ectoderm does not contribute to the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Option C. Mark a. Intraembryonic Mesoderm:

 

  • The intraembryonic mesoderm is a layer of embryonic tissue that gives rise to various structures in the developing embryo, including muscles, bones, and connective tissues.
  • While mesoderm does play a role in the development of the vertebral column and its associated structures, the nucleus pulposus specifically derives from the notochord.

 

Option D. Mark c. Endoderm:

 

  • The endoderm is one of the three primary germ layers of the developing embryo and gives rise to the epithelial linings of various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and other internal organs.
  • The endoderm is not directly involved in the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrulation (Embryonic development of the germ layers):

 

  • Gastrulation is the early embryological process by which an embryo changes from a one-dimensional layer of epithelial cells (blastula) to a multilayered structure known as a gastrula.
  • The notochord is a rod-like embryological structure that is derived during gastrulation and plays an important role in vertebrate development.
  • The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous centre of the intervertebral disc formed by the expansion of the notochord (by its remnants). As a result, it is derived from the notochord.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a holocrine gland? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B

 

The histopathological image marked 'B' represents the sebaceous gland, which is a type of holocrine gland.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A: Image A. Sweat glands - Eccrine/merocrine glands; glands remain intact

 

 

Options C: Image C. Mammary gland - Apocrine gland; apical part sheds to secrete

 

 

Option D: Image D. Ceruminous gland - Apocrine glands

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen.

 

Examples of holocrine glands are: -

 

  • Sebaceous glands of the skin and
  • Meibomian glands of the eyelid

questions.text: Which joint allows for the side-to-side movement of the head, enabling a person to look to the right and left?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atlanto-axial

 

  • The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.
  • The atlanto-axial joints consist of two lateral joints located on either side between the bottom of the atlas bone and the top of the axis bone, which are flat joints.
  • Additionally, there is a central joint between the dens (a protrusion from the axis bone) and the front arch and transverse ligament of the atlas, which is a pivot joint.
  • This central joint has two distinct synovial cavities - one in the front and one in the back.
  • Rotatory movements occur at all three joints and revolve around a vertical axis.
  • The dens acts as a pivot around which the atlas rotates (carrying the skull with it), allowing the head to rotate side to side.
  • The alar ligaments restrict movement. Atlanto-axial rotation has a normal range of about 40°.

 

Atlanto-Axial joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atlanto-occipital joint: This joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the occipital bone of the skull. It primarily permits the "nodding" motion of the head, as in signaling "yes". This joint allows for flexion and extension of the head, but not significant rotation. It's the joint that lets you tilt your head upward or downward.

 

Option C. C2-C3 joint: This joint is between the second and third cervical vertebrae. While it does allow for some degree of rotation, it does not provide the primary rotational movement to look right or left. The range of motion at this joint is less compared to the atlanto-axial joint, and it's more involved in flexion, extension, and some lateral bending.

 

Option D. C3-C4 joint: This joint is between the third and fourth cervical vertebrae. Like the C2-C3 joint, the C3-C4 joint also provides some degree of rotation but not the primary movement. Its main movements are flexion, extension, and lateral bending of the neck. The lower down the cervical spine you go, the less rotational capacity there typically is at each subsequent joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the second cervical vertebra (the axis or C2). The dens or odontoid process, fits into the atlas, allowing for a pivot-like rotation. This is the joint responsible for allowing the rotation of the head from side to side, as in signaling "no" or looking right and left. It provides the majority of the rotational capability of the head.

questions.text: Which of the marked foramen does the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve pass through? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation

 

The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve passes through the foramen ovale which is marked as 4 in the above image.

 

The foramen ovale is also located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.

 

The structure that passes through the foramen ovale is the mandibular nerve (the third division of the trigeminal nerve, Cranial Nerve V3). It carries sensory information from the face and provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.

 

Foramen ovale is situated anterior and medial to foramen spinosum, and is larger in size than spinosum.


Structures passing vis foramen ovale can be remembered by the following mnemonic
M - Mandibular nerve (3rd division of trigeminal)
A - Accessory meningeal artery
L - Lesser petrosal nerve
E - emissary veins
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • The foramen spinosum is a small foramen located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, near the foramen ovale.
  • The structure that passes through the foramen spinosum is the middle meningeal artery. This artery supplies blood to the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

 

Option B. Internal Acoustic Meatus:

 

  • The internal acoustic meatus is located in the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • Several important structures pass through this foramen:
    1. Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII): It carries motor and sensory fibers related to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    2. Vestibulocochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII): It carries sensory information related to hearing and balance.

 

Option C. Jugular Foramen:

 

  • The jugular foramen is located at the junction of the temporal and occipital bones, near the base of the skull.
  • Several structures pass through the jugular foramen:
    1. Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX): It carries motor and sensory fibers to the pharynx and taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    2. Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X): It carries motor and sensory fibers to various organs in the thorax and abdomen and plays a crucial role in autonomic functions.
    3. Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI): It supplies motor fibers to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
    4. Internal jugular vein: It is a major vein that drains blood from the brain and parts of the face.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: How many intrinsic muscles of the hand are supplied by the ulnar nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. 15

 

Explanation:

 

The ulnar nerve supplies 15 intrinsic muscles of the hand. These include all hypothenar muscles (abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi), the palmaris brevis, all four palmar interossei, all four dorsal interossei, the adductor pollicis, and the deep head of flexor pollicis brevis (sometimes). The ulnar nerve is known as the "musician's nerve" because it controls fine movements of the fingers through its extensive motor distribution to these short muscles of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. 5 - This is incorrect. The median nerve supplies 5 muscles in the hand (thenar muscles - abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the first and second lumbricals).
  • Option B. 13 - This is incorrect. The number of intrinsic hand muscles supplied by the ulnar nerve is 15, not 13.
  • Option D. 17 - This is incorrect. The total number of intrinsic muscles in the hand is 20, of which 15 are supplied by the ulnar nerve and 5 by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The ulnar nerve supplies 15 out of the 20 intrinsic muscles of the hand, making it the primary motor nerve of the hand and earning it the title of "musician's nerve" for its role in fine motor control of the fingers.

questions.text: Mention the type of joint present at the marked area: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saddle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the hand, with the arrow pointing to the first carpometacarpal joint, which is the joint between the carpal bone (trapezium) and the first metacarpal bone (base of the thumb). This joint is a classical example of a saddle joint.

 

In a saddle joint, one bone has a concave and convex surface that articulates with the complementary convex and concave surface of the other bone, resembling a saddle shape. The joint is surrounded by a capsule and filled with synovial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ellipsoid: An ellipsoid joint has an oval-shaped articular surface that fits into an elliptical cavity, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option B. Condylar: A condylar joint has an oval projection of one bone fitting into an elliptical cavity of another bone, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option C. Plane: A plane joint has two flat or slightly curved articular surfaces that allow for gliding or sliding movements. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first carpometacarpal joint at the base of the thumb is a saddle joint, allowing a wide range of thumb movements.

Saddle Joint – Mnemonic – PICS

Concavo-convex surface in each bone

P – Patellofemoral joint

I – incudomalleolar joint

C – Carpometacarpal joint

S – Sternoclavicular joint

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

The caudate lobe is a small, distinct lobe of the liver that lies posterior to the porta hepatis and forms the posterior border of the lesser omentum. Importantly, it forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen. Thus, during cholecystectomy, an injury advancing the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen could damage the caudate lobe.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.

 

 

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of bleeding from the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right lobe of liver: The right lobe of the liver is a major lobe, and it constitutes the majority of the liver's mass. It does not directly border the epiploic foramen. The anterior surface of the right lobe faces the anterior abdominal wall, and the posterior surface is related to the diaphragm and right kidney.

 

Option B. Quadrate lobe of liver: The quadrate lobe is a smaller lobe situated on the visceral surface of the liver. It is bounded by the gallbladder on the right and the round ligament of the liver on the left. It is separated from the left lobe by the fissure for the ligamentum teres. While it's close to the region, the quadrate lobe does not form the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Fundus of gallbladder: The fundus is the most distal part of the gallbladder and it usually projects beyond the inferior border of the liver, contacting the anterior abdominal wall. It is not directly related to the epiploic foramen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boundaries of epiploic foramen

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the Green marked structure in the image in anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

questions.text: What is the origin of the fibers marked by the arrow? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above image is the cross-section of the human brain in which the marked arrow indicates the fornix.
  • Fornix belongs to projectional fibers which are the type of white matter fibers. Fornix forms the efferent fibers of the hippocampus and connects it with the mammillary body. Hence the origin of fibers is hippocampus
  • The fornix is a white matter bundle located in the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres which arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.
  • It connects various nodes of a limbic circuitry and is believed to play a key role in cognition and episodic memory recall.
  • Fornix is an example of association fiber and is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • The hippocampus is a seahorse-shaped structure located within the temporal lobes of the brain. The fornix originates from the hippocampus. Specifically, it receives input from the hippocampus and sends axons that project back to the hippocampus. This loop of connections is involved in memory formation and retrieval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Habenular: The habenular nuclei are small structures located near the thalamus and are involved in various functions, including the regulation of the pineal gland's activity. The fornix is not directly associated with the habenular nuclei. Instead, it primarily connects the hippocampus to other structures in the limbic system.

 

Option C. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain. The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies. This connection is an essential component of the Papez circuit, a neural circuit involved in memory and emotion.

 

Option D. Amygdala: The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes and plays a key role in processing emotions, particularly fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala is part of the limbic system, it is not directly connected to the fornix. Instead, the amygdala communicates with other limbic structures through various neural pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The posterior superior iliac spine is at the level of?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. S2

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is an important bony landmark located at the posterior end of the iliac crest. The PSIS lies in the floor of a dimple about 5 cm lateral to the median plane and at the level of the second sacral spine (S2). This dimple is visible on the surface of the body and corresponds to the middle of the sacroiliac joint. The PSIS serves as an important landmark for various clinical examinations and procedures related to the lower back and pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. L5 - The highest point of the iliac crest corresponds to the interval between the spines of L3 and L4 vertebrae, not the PSIS. L5 is lower than this level but still above the level of PSIS.
  • Option B. S1 - The S1 vertebral level is above the level of the PSIS. The S1 foramen is an important landmark for nerve root identification, but it doesn't align with the PSIS.
  • Option D. S3 - The S3 vertebral level is below the level of the PSIS. The PSIS specifically aligns with the S2 vertebral level, not S3.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is located at the level of the second sacral spine (S2) and serves as a clinically important surface landmark for identifying the sacroiliac joint and related structures.

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not carry parasympathetic fibers? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trochlear

 

Explanation:

 

Among the cranial nerves, only the oculomotor (CN III), facial (CN VII), glossopharyngeal (CN IX), and vagus (CN X) nerves carry parasympathetic fibers. These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity in the head, neck, and face area. The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is not involved in parasympathetic innervation.

 

The parasympathetic ganglia associated with these cranial nerves are:

 

  • Oculomotor (CN III): Ciliary ganglion, related to the eye
  • Facial (CN VII): Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia, causing secretion from nasal, palatine, and submandibular glands
  • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): Otic ganglion
  • Vagus (CN X): Responsible for secretion from the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial: The facial nerve (CN VII) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia.

 

Option C. Oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the ciliary ganglion.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the otic ganglion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic fibers are CN III, CN VII, CN IX, and CN X (3, 7, 9, 10). These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity and secretion in the head, neck, and face area, as well as the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: The action of the muscle attached to the marked area? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abduction

 

Explanation:

 

The greater trochanter is visible in the photograph, and the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscle fibres attach (insert) here. Action of these fibres of abducting the leg, and their anterior fibres rotate the thigh medially.

 

Both are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

 

Hip abduction involves moving the thigh laterally, away from the midline. This is the primary function of both the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. When you stand on one leg, these muscles contract on the standing side to prevent the pelvis from tilting down on the free side. This stabilizing action is crucial for bipedal walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion: Hip flexion primarily involves lifting the thigh forward in an anterior direction. While the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus can assist in flexion when the hip is initially in extension, this is not their primary function. Main hip flexors include the iliopsoas, rectus femoris, and sartorius.

 

Option B. Adduction: Hip adduction is the action of moving the thigh medially, towards the midline. Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus are not adductors; in fact, they act in opposition to this movement. The primary hip adductors include muscles like the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, gracilis, and pectineus.

 

Option D. Extension: Hip extension involves moving the thigh posteriorly. The primary hip extensor is the gluteus maximus, which is the largest of the gluteal muscles. While the gluteus medius and minimus can assist in hip extension when the hip is initially flexed, this is not their main action.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Anterior wall of the left ventricle
Inferior surface of the right ventricle

questions.text: A patient with a recent MI underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery. The infarction is likely to be present in which of the following regions of the heart? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior wall of the left ventricle

 

Explanation:

 

The patient with recent myocardial infarction (MI), who underwent coronary angiography, revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD).

 

The LAD is a branch of the left coronary artery and is commonly referred to as the "widow's artery" due to its high incidence of involvement in angina and MI. The LAD runs along the anterior side of the heart and supplies the apex of the ventricle. The left coronary artery is the main artery supplying the left ventricle. Therefore, a block in the LAD would most likely result in an infarction in the anterior wall of the left ventricle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior part of interventricular septum: Incorrect. The posterior part of the interventricular septum is primarily supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is usually a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) or sometimes the left circumflex artery (LCX).

 

Option C. Lateral part of the heart: Incorrect. The lateral part of the heart is mainly supplied by the left circumflex artery (LCX), another branch of the left coronary artery.

 

Option D. Inferior surface of the right ventricle: Incorrect. The inferior surface of the right ventricle is supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA) and its branches, such as the marginal branch and the posterior descending artery (PDA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, and a block in this artery can lead to an infarction in this region of the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

questions.text: During climbing the staircase, a person suddenly fell & a sharp object hit on his neck. Immediately after the injury, the patient developed severe pain and weakness in raising the arm above shoulder level, with noticeable hollowing of the shoulder region. What structure is most likely to be damaged? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The axillary nerve (C5, C6) innervates the deltoid muscle and provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the upper arm. The deltoid muscle is crucial for shoulder abduction (raising the arm away from the body). When the axillary nerve is damaged, patients experience:

 

  • Weakness in arm abduction beyond 15 degrees
  • Atrophy of the deltoid muscle, causing a hollow appearance of the shoulder
  • Sensory loss over the lateral shoulder region
  • Pain in the shoulder region

 

The location of injury and symptoms clearly point to axillary nerve damage, as it runs through the quadrangular space and is vulnerable to injury in the shoulder region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Its injury causes winging of the scapula, not shoulder abduction weakness or hollowing.

 

Option B. Spinal accessory nerve: The spinal accessory nerve innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Its injury would cause difficulty in shoulder shrugging and neck rotation, not arm abduction.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the arm (biceps, brachialis, coracobrachialis). Its injury would primarily affect elbow flexion, not shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary nerve's course through the quadrangular space makes it vulnerable to injury, resulting in deltoid weakness, shoulder pain, and characteristic hollowing of the shoulder region due to muscle atrophy.

questions.text: Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Purkinje cells

 

The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

 

 

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Purkinje cells are specialized neurons located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • They are flask-shaped cells arranged in a single layer with even spacing.
  • Each Purkinje cell has a dendrite that rises from its neck and enters the molecular layer, where it branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell descends, crosses the granular cell layer, and enters the white matter. These axons are the only efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons, which provide inhibitory feedback.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei, where it synapses with other neurons to modulate motor function.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to regulate cerebellar output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: These are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their axons give rise to basket-like formations that surround the soma and initial axon segment of the Purkinje cells.
  • They play a role in modulating the activity of Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Golgi cells: These are also inhibitory interneurons, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their dendrites extend into the molecular layer where they synapse with the parallel fibers of granule cells.
  • Golgi cells provide feedback inhibition to granule cells, modulating their output.

 

Option D. Granule cells:

 

  • These are the most numerous neurons in the brain, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are excitatory neurons that receive input from the cerebellar afferents through the mossy fibers.
  • Their axons ascend into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate and run parallel to the surface, forming the parallel fibers. These fibers synapse with the dendrites of the Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are among the largest neurons in the brain, located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have a large, flask-shaped soma from which extend many branching dendrites. The dendritic tree is oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the cerebellum, extending into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells pass into the white matter and are the only axons that leave the cerebellar cortex to synapse with cells in the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which joint is not formed by the bone shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

The structure marked in the image is the fibula's neck.

 

The common peroneal nerve supplies motor fibers to the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, including the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles, which evert the foot and plantarflex the ankle joint. It also provides sensory fibers to the skin over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.

 

Injuries to the common peroneal nerve can occur due to trauma or compression, and can result in weakness or paralysis of the muscles it innervates, as well as sensory loss over the affected area. Common peroneal nerve injuries can be treated with conservative measures such as physiotherapy or surgery in severe cases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is a sensory nerve in the calf region. It is formed by branches from both the common peroneal and tibial nerves. The sural nerve provides sensation to the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot. It runs more distally in the leg and is not closely associated with the neck of the fibula.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve is another major branch of the sciatic nerve. After the division of the sciatic nerve, the tibial nerve continues its course in the posterior compartment of the leg, supplying muscles there and then continuing into the foot. It is primarily responsible for plantar flexion of the foot and toe flexion. The tibial nerve does not have a close relation with the neck of the fibula as it runs more medially in the leg.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh. It is responsible for hip flexion and knee extension. This nerve is located in the anterior aspect of the thigh, far away from the neck of the fibula, and has no direct relation with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Common peroneal nerve (also known as common fibular nerve), a significant branch of the sciatic nerve, follows a course along the thigh's posterior compartment and wraps around the fibula's neck, making it susceptible to injury. After encircling the fibula, it splits into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves, which innervate the leg's lateral and anterior compartments and contribute sensory functions to parts of the foot.

questions.text: The axillary artery is divided into three parts by?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Pectoralis minor

 

Explanation: 

 

The axillary artery is divided into three distinct parts by the pectoralis minor muscle. This key muscle of the axillary region serves as an important anatomical landmark that helps segment the axillary artery for descriptive purposes. Each part of the axillary artery gives specific branches: the first part (proximal to pectoralis minor) gives the superior thoracic artery; the second part (behind pectoralis minor) gives the thoracoacromial and lateral thoracic arteries; and the third part (distal to pectoralis minor) gives the anterior circumflex humeral, posterior circumflex humeral, and subscapular arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Scalenus anterior - This muscle divides the subclavian artery into three parts, not the axillary artery. The subclavian artery becomes the axillary artery as it crosses the outer border of the first rib.
  • Option C. Teres minor - This muscle forms part of the rotator cuff and is related to the posterior wall of the axilla. It doesn't divide the axillary artery but forms part of the boundary of the quadrangular space.
  • Option D. Teres major - This muscle forms the lower boundary of the posterior wall of the axilla. The axillary artery ends at the lower border of teres major to become the brachial artery, but teres major doesn't divide the axillary artery into parts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pectoralis minor is the key muscle that divides the axillary artery into three parts, with each part giving rise to specific branches that supply the pectoral region and upper limb.

questions.text: From which structure do the alae of the nose develop? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral nasal process

 

Explanation:

 

The development of the face involves five processes: the frontonasal process, medial nasal processes, lateral nasal processes, maxillary processes, and mandibular processes.

 

The central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, develops from the midline frontonasal process. As the nasal pits develop, they give rise to the medial and lateral nasal processes on each side.

 

The alae of the nose, which are the lateral flaring parts of the nostrils, develop from the lateral nasal processes.

 

The maxillary processes give rise to the maxillae, while the mandibular processes form the mandible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontonasal process: Incorrect. The frontonasal process gives rise to the central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, but not the alae.

 

Option B. Medial nasal process: Incorrect. The medial nasal processes contribute to the formation of the median part of the nose, but not the alae.

 

Option D. Bucconasal membrane: Incorrect. The bucconasal membrane is not one of the five processes involved in facial development and does not give rise to the alae of the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The alae of the nose develop from the lateral nasal processes during facial development.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not present in which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

Reticular fibres are not present in the thymus. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ involved in the development and maturation of T lymphocytes (T cells) and does not contain a significant amount of reticular fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes contain reticular fibers within their structure. Reticular fibers in lymph nodes create a network that supports immune cells, such as lymphocytes and macrophages, as they filter and process lymphatic fluid.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow: Reticular fibers are found in the bone marrow. They contribute to the framework of the bone marrow, supporting blood-forming cells and various hematopoietic elements involved in blood cell production.

 

Option D. Spleen: Reticular fibers are present in the spleen. Similar to lymph nodes, the spleen contains reticular fibers that support immune cells and help filter blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular fibres:

 

A form of connective tissue fibre known as reticular fibres, reticular fibres, or reticulin is made of type III collagen released by reticular cells. Crosslinking reticular fibres create a delicate meshwork (reticulin). Soft tissues like the liver, bone marrow, and the tissues and organs of the lymphatic system benefit from the support provided by this network.

 

They differ from type I collagen fibres in that, they are finer and are arranged in the form of a network (reticulum). The fibres appear black in colour on staining with silver impregnation. Due to this affinity to silver salts, they are also known as argentophil fibres.

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anterior compartment of the forearm, focusing on the tendons near the wrist. The arrow is pointing to a tendon that runs from the forearm to the wrist and to the palm. This tendon belongs to the flexor carpi radialis muscle. The flexor carpi radialis is one of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm. It plays a crucial role in flexion and abduction of the wrist.

 

Flexor Carpi Radialis: The flexor carpi radialis tendon is located just lateral to the palmaris longus tendon. It is prominent and easily palpable in many individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris: This is incorrect. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is located medial to the palmaris longus tendon and runs towards the pisiform bone.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis: This is incorrect. The flexor digitorum superficialis tendons are deeper and run to the fingers, responsible for flexion of the middle phalanges.

 

Option D. Palmaris longus: This is incorrect. The palmaris longus tendon runs from the forearm to the palm and is more centrally located in the wrist. It is a thin tendon that is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm with a prominent tendon that runs from the forearm to the base of the second and third metacarpals, playing a key role in wrist flexion and abduction.

questions.text:
Which of the provided statements about the muscle depicted in the image are true? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius
  2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius
  3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
  4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

Marked muscle in the image given is Rhomboid Major and minor.

 

 

1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. Both the rhomboideus major and minor muscles play a role in scapular retraction. This means they help pull the scapula (shoulder blade) toward the midline of the body, which is an action involved in retracting the scapula. The middle fibers of the trapezius muscle also contribute to scapular retraction.
     

2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. The Rhomboids retract the scapula superiorly and medially from the medial border of the scapula, this in turn assists in elevation of the scapula along with upper fibers of trapezius..
     

3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly:

 

  • True. When scapula is retracted and elevated along the medial border by rhomboids the glenoid cavity turns inferiorly (the socket of the shoulder joint).

     

Other Option:
 

4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly:

 

  • False. The primary action of the rhomboideus major and minor muscles is not to tilt the glenoid cavity superiorly. Their main functions involve scapular retraction and elevation, as discussed in statements 1 and 2. Tilted movement of the glenoid cavity superiorly is not a primary function associated with these muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rhomboid Major and Minor muscles are key players in scapular stabilization, involved in retraction, elevation, and downward rotation of the scapula, aligning the glenoid cavity in a position that supports optimal shoulder function.

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the prominent nerve pointed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Great auricular nerve

 

The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve.

 

 

Great auricular nerve:

 

  • The great auricular nerve is the cervical plexus's largest ascending branch, arising from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.
  • The nerve emerges just behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle's middle portion, curves around its posterior border, and emerges on the muscle's anterior surface.
  • The great auricular nerve perforates the deep cervical fascia and ascends along the external jugular vein, passing under the platysma muscle.
  • The great auricular nerve divides into terminal branches as it approaches the parotid gland.

 

Clinical considerations:

 

  • ﻿﻿Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (As seen in the above image)
  • ﻿﻿Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesser Occipital Nerve: The lesser occipital nerve is another branch of the cervical plexus, arising from the second cervical spinal nerve (C2). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the posterior part of the scalp.

 

Option C. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve, also known as the seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), is a mixed nerve responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression. It also carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It does not primarily provide sensory innervation to the skin.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal Nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). It supplies sensory innervation to the external ear and the skin of the temple region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically originating from the second and third cervical spinal nerves (C2-C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the external ear, and the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: A patient has had his molar teeth extracted, following which he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lingual nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The innervation of the tongue is divided into three parts: anterior two-thirds, posterior one-third, and posterior most part.

 

The anterior two-thirds of the tongue is derived from the first pharyngeal arch, innervated by the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, supplies general sensation (pain, temperature, and touch) to this part of the tongue. However, taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).

 

The posterior one-third of the tongue is derived from the third pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which carries both general and taste sensation.

 

The posterior most part of the tongue is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X), which carries both general and taste sensation.

 

Tongue development:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. The glossopharyngeal nerve innervates the posterior one-third of the tongue, not the anterior two-thirds.

 

Option B. Hypoglossal nerve: Incorrect. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to the tongue muscles and does not carry sensory fibers.

 

Option C. Inferior alveolar nerve: Incorrect. The inferior alveolar nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve that supplies the lower teeth, gingiva, and lower lip, but not the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (trigeminal nerve), supplies general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone. The foramen marked is the foramen rotundum. Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve passes through it.

 

 

The foramen rotundum is a small circular opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull. It serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

The maxillary nerve exits the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and then travels through the pterygopalatine fossa, where it gives off several branches that innervate the maxillary teeth, the maxillary sinus, and the skin of the face in the maxillary region.

 

Other structures that may pass through the foramen rotundum include small blood vessels and veins, but these are less significant than the maxillary nerve in terms of clinical relevance.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Foramen Ovale:

 

  • Location: The foramen ovale is also located in the sphenoid bone, adjacent (Postero- lateral) to the foramen rotundum.
  • Contents: It transmits the mandibular nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve or CN V3), the accessory meningeal artery, and sometimes a small emissary vein.

 

Option C. Vidian Canal (Pterygoid Canal):

 

  • Location: The vidian canal is a small canal in the sphenoid bone, extending from the pterygopalatine fossa to the middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents: It contains the vidian nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), as well as the vidian artery and sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • Location: The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is present postero-lateral to foramen ovale
  • Contents: It transmits the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, and the middle meningeal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.

 

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A - Hyoid bone

B - Thyroid cartilage

C - Epiglottis

D - Cricoid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.
