Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage  which belongs to larynx located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:

 

  • Hyaline cartilage: The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • Elastic cartilage: The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: The marked landmark corresponds to which structure?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Marked landmark corresponds to ulnar nerve

 

Arrow points toward the medial epicondyle and Ulnar nerve passes below it.

 

The ulnar nerve gives no branches in the arm. It runs distally through the axilla medial to the axillary artery and between it and the vein, continuing distally medial to the brachial artery as far as the midarm. Here it pierces the medial intermuscular septum, inclining medially as it descends anterior to the medial head of triceps to the interval between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon, with the superior ulnar collateral artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve enters the arm lateral to the brachial artery. Near the insertion of coracobrachialis it crosses in front of the artery, descending medial to it to the cubital fossa where it is posterior to the bicipital aponeurosis and anterior to brachialis, separated by the latter from the elbow joint.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: supplies the long head of triceps, and gives rise to the posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm which supplies the skin along the posterior surface of the upper arm. It then spirals obliquely across the back of the humerus, lying posterior to the uppermost fibres of the medial head of triceps which separate the nerve from the bone in the first part of the spiral groove. On reaching the lateral side of the humerus it pierces the lateral intermuscular septum to enter the anterior compartment; it then descends deep in a furrow between brachialis and proximally brachioradialis, then more distally extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the anterior rami (branches) of the spinal nerves C5, C6, and C7. After its origin, the musculocutaneous nerve courses downward through the axilla (armpit) alongside the axillary artery. It then enters the anterior compartment of the arm by piercing through the coracobrachialis muscle. It provide motor innervation to the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. These muscles include coracobrachialis and biceps brachii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

 

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus.

questions.text: Identify the muscle forming the marked boundary: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anatomical snuff box, a triangular depression at the base of the thumb. The anatomical snuff box has specific boundaries, and the arrow is pointing to the posterior (posteromedial) boundary. The muscle forming the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box is the extensor pollicis longus.

 

 

The mnemonic "aage longus peechhe longus beech mein brevis" helps remember the boundaries:

 

  • Anterior (anterolateral) boundary: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
  • Posterior (posteromedial) boundary: Extensor pollicis longus
  • Between the two boundaries: Extensor pollicis brevis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor pollicis brevis: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary and the floor of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.

 

Option B. Abductor pollicis longus: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is not related to the boundaries of the anatomical snuff box. It is a muscle of the thenar eminence, responsible for abduction of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extensor pollicis longus forms the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box.

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the embryological basis for the formation of an omphalocele? ( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

questions.text: The given arrow corresponds to which level of thoracic vertebra? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fourth and Fifth

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the above image represents the sternal angle (Angle of Louis), which corresponds to the T4-T5 intervertebral disc.

The "angle of Louis," also known as the "sternal angle" or "manubriosternal joint," is an anatomical landmark located in the chest area. The angle of Louis is located at the junction of two important anatomical structures:

 

  • The manubrium of the sternum: This is the uppermost part of the sternum (breastbone) and is shaped like a flat, triangular bone.
  • The body of the sternum: This is the long, flat portion of the sternum that extends downward from the manubrium.

 

Clinical Significance: The angle of Louis is a clinically significant reference point because it corresponds to the level of several important anatomical structures:

It is located at the approximate level of the second rib anteriorly. This makes it useful for counting ribs and identifying rib fractures or landmarks during clinical examinations.

It is also close to the carina of the trachea, which is a critical point in the respiratory system where the trachea divides into the left and right main bronchi.

The angle of Louis serves as a reference for the superior border of the heart and is used in clinical assessments such as cardiac auscultation.Top of Form

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) First and Second Thoracic Vertebrae (T1 and T2): The first thoracic vertebra (T1) is located just below the seventh cervical vertebra (C7). It marks the transition from the cervical spine to the thoracic spine. The second thoracic vertebra (T2) is located just below T1 and continues the thoracic spine.

 

Option B) Second and Third Thoracic Vertebrae (T2 and T3): These vertebrae are adjacent to each other, with T2 immediately below T1 and T3 following T2.

 

Option D) Fifth and sixth Thoracic Vertebrae ( T5 and T6): This option suggests that the arrow corresponds to the region between the fifth and sixth thoracic vertebrae which is lower than the marked arrow in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Sternal angle / Angle of Louis -
    • Between Manubrium & Body of sternum
    • Lies at level of Lower border of T4

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is one of the three layers of the cerebellar cortex, along with the granular layer and the Purkinje cell layer. It is involved in the processing of sensory information, as well as motor planning and coordination. The stellate and basket cells within the molecular layer provide inhibitory feedback to the Purkinje cells, which are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

 

The parallel fibres, which originate from granule cells in the granular layer, run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and provide excitatory input to the molecular layer. As the parallel fibres traverse the molecular layer, they make multiple synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells, where inhibitory synapses are formed. This allows the Purkinje cells to integrate the incoming excitatory and inhibitory signals and adjust their output accordingly.

 

Overall, the molecular layer plays a crucial role in the cerebellar circuitry and contributes to the precision of motor movements and balance.

 

 

1. Stellate cells:

  • Location: Stellate cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are inhibitory interneurons that primarily release GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and inhibit the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
     

2. Basket cells:

  • Location: Basket cells are also located in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are another type of inhibitory interneuron. The axons of basket cells form "baskets" around the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, releasing GABA and inhibiting them.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Purkinje cells:

  • Location: Purkinje cells form their own distinct layer known as the Purkinje cell layer, which is situated between the molecular layer and the granular layer.
  • Function: These cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They have large, flattened dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer, receiving inputs from climbing fibers and parallel fibers. The axons of Purkinje cells send inhibitory projections to the cerebellar nuclei.
     

4. Granular cells:

  • Location: Granular cells are present in the granular layer, which is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Function: These cells receive inputs from mossy fibers, which originate from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. Granular cells send their axons into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate to form parallel fibers. These parallel fibers synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: The green-shaded region in the coronal section of the brain corresponds to which type of fibers? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Projection

 

The internal capsule, a type of projection fibre, is the marked structure.

 

Projection fibres -

 

  • Connect the cerebral cortex to other brain areas and the spinal cord.
  • These fibers run vertically, either ascending to the cortex (afferent fibers bringing in sensory information) or descending from the cortex (efferent fibers sending out motor commands).
  • The corona radiata and the internal capsule are examples of areas containing many projection fibers.
  • They facilitate communication between the cortex and other parts of the CNS like the brainstem, thalamus, and spinal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Association:

 

  • Also known as "U-fibers" or "short arcuate fibers" which connect neighboring gyrus.
  • They allow for communication between adjacent or nearby cortical regions.
  • Primarily found in the gray matter just below the cortical surface.
  • Their presence helps in localized processing and integration of information within a single cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Long Association:

 

  • Connect more distant areas within the same hemisphere.
  • Examples include the superior longitudinal fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the posterior temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, and the uncinate fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the anterior temporal lobe.
  • These fibers are crucial for integrating information across distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere.

 

Option D. Commissural:

 

  • Connect corresponding regions of the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing them to communicate with each other.
  • The most prominent example is the corpus callosum, which is the largest white matter structure in the brain and provides a broad band of neural connections between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. Other examples include the anterior commissure and the posterior commissure.
  • These fibers are essential for the two hemispheres to share information and coordinate activity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A newborn presents with intestinal contents protruding through a defect lateral to the umbilicus, with no membrane covering. The baby also has evidence of intestinal atresia. Identify the most likely diagnosis: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario describes gastroschisis, characterized by:

  • Defect lateral (usually right) to intact umbilical cord
  • No covering membrane/sac
  • Direct exposure of bowel to amniotic fluid
  • High association with intestinal atresia (10-15% cases)
  • Typically an isolated defect
  • Smaller defect (2-4 cm) compared to omphalocele

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele:

  • Central defect at umbilicus
  • Covered by membrane (amnion, peritoneum, Wharton's jelly)
  • Associated with chromosomal anomalies
  • Not typically associated with intestinal atresia

 

Option B. Umbilical hernia:

  • Protrusion through umbilical ring
  • Covered by skin
  • Usually contains only omentum
  • No association with intestinal atresia

 

Option D. Omphalocele with gastric duplication:

  • Would have membrane covering
  • Central defect
  • Gastric duplications are rare
  • Not typically associated with intestinal atresia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key differences between gastroschisis and omphalocele is crucial:

  1. Location of defect (lateral vs central)
  2. Presence/absence of covering membrane
  3. Associated anomalies (intestinal atresia in gastroschisis vs chromosomal anomalies in omphalocele)
  4. Size of defect and contents

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Portal vein

 

The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

 

The portal vein is a significant vessel that delivers blood from the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, pancreas, and gallbladder to the liver.

 

In the context of Couinaud's classification, the liver is divided into right and left lobes by the main portal vein. Further segmentation divides each lobe into individual segments based on the branches of the portal vein. As such, the portal vein is the primary structure used in Couinaud's system to determine liver segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery: The hepatic artery provides oxygen-rich blood to the liver. While it is part of the portal triad and serves individual liver segments, it is not the primary structure used to define the segments in Couinaud's classification. The segmentation is based on the portal vein's distribution, although the hepatic artery's branches supply the respective segments concurrently.

 

Option C. Bile duct: The bile ducts are responsible for transporting bile produced in the liver to the gallbladder for storage or directly to the small intestine for digestion. Similar to the hepatic artery, while bile ducts are part of the portal triad and serve individual liver segments, they aren't the primary structure used for segmentation in the Couinaud's system.

 

Option D. Cystic duct: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. It does not have a direct role in dividing the liver into its segments and is unrelated to Couinaud's classification system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Illustration of the segmental anatomy of the liver based on the third-order portal vein branching (Couinaud's classification system) and the portal vein and hepatic vein branches.

 

IVC: inferior vena cava and PV: portal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following structures marked in the below image gives rise to the heart in an adult? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. D

 

Explanation:

 

The above image is of the embryo and the structure which gives rise to the heart in an adult is the heart bulge (Cardiac cushion)- a structure marked as ‘D’.

 

The marked structure in the given diagram are

 

A - Head

B – Primitive lens

C – Pharyngeal arches

D – Heart bulge

E – liver bulge

F – Limb bud

G – Leg Bud

H – Tail

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E (Liver bulge): Does not develop into the heart.

 

Option C. F (Limb bud): Develops into limbs, not cardiac structures.

 

Option D. A (Head): Develops into head structures, not the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detailed Developmental stages:

 

1. Early Formation:

 

  • In the third week of embryonic development, paired strands of lateral plate mesoderm called the "cardiogenic mesoderm" or "cardiogenic fields" begin to form in the anterior region of the embryonic disc.
  • These strands coalesce in the midline of the embryo to form the "cardiac crescent" or "heart bulge".

 

2. Heart Tube Formation:

 

  • By the beginning of the fourth week, as the embryo undergoes lateral folding, the cardiac crescent fuses in the midline to form a straight heart tube. This tube comprises an outer myocardial layer and an inner endocardial layer with a cardiac jelly in between.

 

3. Differential Growth and Looping:

 

  • Soon after its formation, the heart tube undergoes differential growth which leads it to elongate. This elongation and subsequent bending result in the process called "cardiac looping", where the tube forms a C-shaped loop.
  • The original straight tube's sections become discernible regions: the sinus venosus, atrium, ventricle, bulbus cordis, and truncus arteriosus (from caudal to cranial).

 

4. Partitioning:

 

  • The single atrium and ventricle of the looped heart tube undergo partitioning (septation) to form the four chambers of the mature heart.
  • The atrioventricular canal, initially a single passage between the atrium and ventricle, is also divided.

 

5. Formation of Outflow Tracts:

 

  • The bulbus cordis and truncus arteriosus undergo remodeling to give rise to the roots and initial portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery.

 

6. Incorporation of Sinus Venosus:

 

  • Initially, the sinus venosus, which receives all the embryonic venous return, opens into the right side of the primitive atrium. With time, the right side of the sinus venosus is incorporated into the forming right atrium, giving rise to the smooth part of its interior (sinus venarum).

 

7. Valve Formation:

 

  • Valves form from endocardial cushions in the atrioventricular canal and from additional cushions in the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis.

 

8. Maturation:

 

  • By the end of the embryonic period (8th week), the heart looks much like it will at birth, though further growth and maturation will occur during the fetal period.

questions.text: Structure lies in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle all except (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tail of caudate nucleus

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn, not the floor.

 

Roof of Inferior horn - Tapetum (part of the corpus callosum), medial part of tail of the Caudate Nucleus and Striate Terminus

 

Floor of Inferior horn – Fimbria, hippocampus, collateral sulcus and collateral eminence.

 

Other Options:

 

The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is a part of the brain located in the temporal lobe. Structures found in the floor of the inferior horn include the hippocampus, fimbria, and collateral eminence.

 

Option A. Collateral eminence: This is a ridge in the floor of the inferior horn formed by the collateral sulcus.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: A crucial structure for memory conversion, located in the floor of the inferior horn.

 

Option C. Fimbria: A bundle of nerve fibers on the hippocampus that forms part of the floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, not in the floor.

choices.text: Medial nasal and lateral nasal process

questions.text: The following image is due to defect in fusion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medial nasal and maxillary process

 

Explanation:

 

Above image is showing Cleft lip; it is due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal and maxillary process.

 

In embryonic development, the face forms from a series of swellings and processes. The medial nasal process contributes to the formation of the middle part of the upper lip, philtrum, and part of the nasal septum. The maxillary process gives rise to the upper jaw and the lateral parts of the upper lip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Medial Nasal and Lateral Nasal Process: The medial nasal process and lateral nasal process are both involved in the formation of the nose and upper lip. The medial nasal process contributes to the middle part of the upper lip and part of the nasal septum. The lateral nasal process forms the sides of the nose.

 

Option C)  Maxillary and Mandibular Process: The maxillary process, as mentioned earlier, contributes to the upper jaw and lateral parts of the upper lip. The mandibular process, on the other hand, forms the lower jaw or mandible. These two processes are essential for the formation of the upper and lower jaws, respectively.

 

Option D) Lateral Nasal and Maxillary Process: The lateral nasal process, as mentioned earlier, contributes to the sides of the nose. The maxillary process, as mentioned earlier, forms the upper jaw and lateral parts of the upper lip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLEFT LIP VS CLEFT LIP AND CLEFT PALATE.

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicants is all except: (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Preganglionic

 

Explanation:

 

  • The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers.
  • In contrast, the white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the spinal nerve to the sympathetic chain ganglia. Once in the ganglia, these fibers either synapse with postganglionic neurons, which return via the grey rami to spinal nerves, or ascend or descend to synapse at other levels.
  • The sympathetic trunks on either side of the vertebral columns consist of a series of ganglia. They are connected to the spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicantes. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic neurons are located in the lateral horn in the spinal grey matter. They leave the cord in the ventral nerve roots to form spinal nerves. These fibers enter the sympathetic trunk in white rami communicantes.
  • They synapse with the postganglionic sympathetic neurons in the sympathetic ganglia. The axons of the postganglionic neurons return to the spinal nerve through the grey rami communicantes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unmyelinated: True. Grey rami communicantes primarily contain unmyelinated postganglionic sympathetic fibers. These fibers are responsible for conveying the postganglionic sympathetic impulses to the spinal nerves, which then distribute these impulses to their target tissues.

 

Option B. Connected to spinal nerve: True. Grey rami communicantes connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to the adjacent spinal nerves. They are responsible for transmitting postganglionic sympathetic fibers to all spinal nerves (regardless of whether or not the spinal nerve level has a white ramus communicans).

 

Option D. Present medial to white rami communicantes: True. Anatomically, when observing the sympathetic chain and its connections to the spinal nerves, the grey rami communicantes are located medially (or more centrally) relative to the white rami communicantes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grey rami communicantes contain postganglionic, unmyelinated fibers that connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to spinal nerves, facilitating the distribution of sympathetic impulses to the body, contrasting with the preganglionic fibers found in white rami communicantes.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from a squatting position. The patient also shows waddling gait. On examination, there is weakness in extending the knee. Identify the nerve injured: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral nerve (L2-L4) is crucial for:

  • Knee extension (via quadriceps femoris)
  • Hip flexion (via iliopsoas)
  • Anterior thigh sensation

 

When injured, patients present with:

  • Difficulty climbing stairs (quadriceps weakness)
  • Trouble rising from squatting position
  • Waddling gait due to proximal muscle weakness
  • Decreased/absent patellar reflex
  • Sensory loss over anterior thigh

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior gluteal nerve:

  • Innervates gluteus medius, minimus, and tensor fasciae latae
  • Injury causes positive Trendelenburg sign
  • Does not affect knee extension or stair climbing

 

Option C. Common peroneal nerve:

  • Affects foot dorsiflexion and eversion
  • Causes foot drop
  • No effect on knee extension or proximal muscle strength

 

Option D. Tibial nerve:

  • Affects plantar flexion and inversion
  • No impact on knee extension or proximal muscle function
  • Sensory loss in sole of foot

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Femoral nerve injury presents with characteristic proximal muscle weakness affecting daily activities like stair climbing and rising from squatting

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of lamellar bone? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Haversian system

 

Explanation:

 

The Haversian system (also called osteon) is the fundamental structural unit of compact lamellar bone. It's the defining microscopic feature of mature lamellar bone. Lamellar bone has a highly organized structure with thin sheets called lamellae arranged in concentric rings around a central Haversian canal, forming the complete Haversian system.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Bone marrow - While bone marrow is found within bones, it's not a characteristic feature of lamellar bone specifically. Bone marrow occupies the medullary cavity of long bones and spaces within cancellous bone but isn't part of the lamellar bone structure itself.
  • Option C. Strength and lightness - Though lamellar bone provides strength and lamellar arrangement contributes to mechanical properties; this is a functional characteristic rather than a structural feature. The Haversian system is the defining structural characteristic.
  • Option D. Trabeculae - Trabeculae are characteristic of cancellous/spongy bone, not compact lamellar bone. Trabeculae are meshworks of bony plates or rods that form the structure of spongy bone. Trabeculae do not contain Haversian systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Haversian system (osteon) is the defining microscopic structural unit of compact lamellar bone, consisting of concentric lamellae around a central canal containing blood vessels and nerves.

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the costal cartilages of the 8th and 9th ribs as they articulate with the 7th rib? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

 

The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

 

  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity containing synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movement.
  • While costovertebral joints are typically not classified as synovial joints, some costovertebral joints do have a limited degree of synovial joint characteristics, especially in the upper thoracic region.
  • While the costal cartilages themselves are cartilaginous structures, the joints between the 5th to 9th costal cartilages are specifically synovial in nature.
     

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

 

  • Synarthrosis- A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrocartilage, a type of cartilage that contains both fibrous and cartilaginous components.
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include the intervertebral discs in the spine and the pubic symphysis in the pelvis. These joints allow for limited movement and provide support and shock absorption.

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are a specific type of cartilaginous joint where two bones are joined by a broad, flat disc of fibrocartilage. These joints are typically immovable or have limited movement.
  • The pubic symphysis, mentioned earlier, is a common example of a symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. Fibrous Joint:

 

  • Fibrous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue between bones. They are immovable or allow for very limited movement.
  • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the gomphosis joint between the teeth and their sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Broca's area is located in which part of the cerebral cortex? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior frontal gyrus

 

Broca's area is primarily located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, specifically within the left hemisphere. It is divided into two regions: Brodmann area 44 (Broca's area proper) and Brodmann area 45 (Pars triangularis). This region is crucial for language production, including the ability to form grammatically correct sentences and articulate speech.

 

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is typically the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals and a significant portion of left-handed individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superior Temporal Gyrus: While the superior temporal gyrus is involved in language processing, it is not the primary site for speech production or Broca's area. Instead, the superior temporal gyrus is associated with auditory processing and speech comprehension.

 

Areas present in superior temporal gyrus: 

 

Brodmann Area 41 (Primary Auditory Cortex) is primarily responsible for the initial processing of auditory information. It receives and processes auditory signals from the ears and is involved in basic sound perception.

 

Brodmann Area 42 (Auditory Association Cortex) is involved in higher-level auditory processing. It helps in recognizing complex auditory stimuli, such as speech, music, and environmental sounds

 

Option C. Angular Gyrus: The angular gyrus, located in the parietal lobe, is involved in various functions, including reading, writing, and language comprehension. It plays a role in translating visual information into language.

 

Areas present in angular gyrus is Brodmann Area 39. It is associated with processes like reading, writing, and language comprehension. It also plays a role in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information, contributing to our ability to understand and interpret the world around us.

 

Option D. Postcentral Gyrus: The postcentral gyrus is located in the parietal lobe and is primarily associated with sensory functions, particularly somatosensory processing. It is not directly involved in speech production or language processing. Brodmann Area 3, 1, and 2 (Primary Somatosensory Cortex): These areas together make up the primary somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus. It is responsible for our ability to perceive sensations such as touch, pressure, temperature, and proprioception (awareness of body position).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

  • Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.
